Spectrum¶

synopsis:A package with many different spectra objects for easy manipulation

spectrum is a package containing many different specrum objects. It defines many useful objects that may be used in the grid_tools package and the model package.

Full-featured spectrum objects¶

These objects may be a little bit slow, but they are designed for convenience to manipulate spectra (convolve, etc) while being robust to check and handle errors.

Log Lambda spectrum¶

A spectrum spaced linear in log lambda has equal-velocity pixels, meaning that

\[\frac{v}{c} = \frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda}\]

A log lambda spectrum is defined by the WCS keywords CDELT1, CRVAL1, and NAXIS1. They are related to the physical wavelengths by the following relationship

\[\lambda = 10^{{\rm CRVAL1} + {\rm CDELT1} \times i}\]

where \(i\) is the pixel index, with \(i = 0\) referring to the first pixel and \(i = ({\rm NAXIS1} - 1)\) referring to the last pixel.

The wavelength array and header keywords are often stored in a wl_dict dictionary, which looks like {"wl":wl, "CRVAL1":CRVAL1, "CDELT1":CDELT1, "NAXIS1":NAXIS1}.

These keywords are related to various wavelengths by

\[\frac{v}{c} = \frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda} = 10^{\rm CDELT1} - 1\]
\[{\rm CDELT1} = \log_{10} \left ( \frac{v}{c} + 1 \right )\]
\[{\rm CRVAL1} = \log_{10} ( \lambda_{\rm start})\]
StellarSpectra.spectrum.log_lam_kws¶

The parameters that define a log lambda spectrum. This set is use to validate input. By default these are set to

log_lam_kws = frozenset(("CDELT1", "CRVAL1", "NAXIS1"))
StellarSpectra.spectrum.create_log_lam_grid(wl_start=3000.0, wl_end=13000.0, min_wl=None, min_vc=None)[source]¶

Create a log lambda spaced grid with N_points equal to a power of 2 for ease of FFT.

Parameters:
  • wl_start (float) – starting wavelength (inclusive)
  • wl_end (float) – ending wavelength (inclusive)
  • min_wl ((delta_wl, wl)) – wavelength spacing at a specific wavelength
  • min_vc (float) – tightest spacing
Returns:

a wavelength dictionary containing the specified properties.
Return type:

wl_dict

Takes the finer of min_WL or min_vc if both specified

The LogLambdaSpectrum is more of a workhorse than the previously defined spectra. Because it is regularly spaced in velocity, it is easier to perform convolution and downsampling operations.

class StellarSpectra.spectrum.LogLambdaSpectrum(wl, fl, unit='f_lam', air=True, metadata=None, oversampling=3.5)[source]¶

A spectrum that has log lambda spaced wavelengths.

Parameters:
  • wl (np.array) – wavelength array
  • fl (np.array) – flux array
  • unit – flux unit (f_lam, or f_nu)
  • air (bool) – is wavelength array measured in air?
  • metadata – any extra metadata associated with the spectrum
  • oversampling (float) – how many samples fit across the FWHM

All of the class methods modify wl and fl in place.

Note

Because of the difficulty of keeping track of convolution, you only get to do {instrument_convolve(), stellar_convolve()} or instrument_and_stellar_convolve() once.

resample_to_grid(wl_dict, integrate=False)[source]¶

Resample/interate the spectrum to a new log lambda grid. Updates the wl, fl, and log_lam_kws in the metadata. This method is slightly different than Base1DSpectrum.resample_to_grid() since it uses wl_dict to ensure that the spectrum remains log lambda spaced and N_points is a power of 2.

Parameters:
  • wl_dict (dict) – dictionary of log lam wavelength properties to resample to
  • integrate (bool) – integrate flux to counts/pixel?

Note

Assumes that new wl grid does not violate any sampling rules and updates header values.

stellar_convolve(vsini)[source]¶

Broaden spectrum due to stellar rotation.

Parameters:vsini (float (km/s)) – projected rotational speed of star
write_to_FITS(out_unit, filename)[source]¶

Write a LogLambdaSpectrum to a FITS file.

Parameters:
  • out_unit (string) – f_lam, f_nu, f_nu_log, or counts/pix
  • filename (string) – output filename

Depending on the out_unit, the spectrum may be converted.

  • f_lam: keep flux units the same
  • f_nu: convert flux to ergs/s/cm^2/Hz
  • f_nu_log: convert flux to ergs/s/cm^2/log(Hz)
  • counts/pix: integrate spectrum to counts/pixel

Fast spectrum objects¶

These spectra assume many properties of the data and are built for speedy comparions via model

class StellarSpectra.spectrum.DataSpectrum(wls, fls, sigmas, masks=None, orders='all')[source]¶

Object to manipulate the data spectrum.

Parameters:
  • wls (1D or 2D np.array) – wavelength (in AA)
  • fls (1D or 2D np.array) – flux (in f_lam)
  • sigmas (1D or 2D np.array) – Poisson noise (in f_lam)
  • masks (1D or 2D np.array of boolean values) – Mask to blot out bad pixels or emission regions.

If the wl, fl, are provided as 1D arrays (say for a single order), they will be converted to 2D arrays with length 1 in the 0-axis.

Note

For now, the DataSpectrum wls, fls, sigmas, and masks must be a rectangular grid. No ragged Echelle orders allowed.

class StellarSpectra.spectrum.ModelSpectrum(interpolator, instrument)[source]¶

A 1D synthetic spectrum.

Parameters:
  • interpolator (grid_tools.ModelInterpolator) – object to query stellar parameters
  • instrument (grid_tools.Instrument object describing wavelength range and instrumental profile) – Which instrument is this a model for?

We essentially want to preserve two capabilities.

  1. Sample in all “stellar parameters” at once
  2. Sample in only the easy “post-processing” parameters, like ff and v_z to speed the burn-in process.
